1.1 Introduction - Part 1
The Vavuniya Campus of the University of Jaffna was established on 1st April 1997 by an order made under Section 22 of the Universities Act No. 16 of 1978 with two faculties, namely, the Faculty of Applied Science and the Faculty of Business Studies. The Faculty of Technological Studies was established in February 2020 (No. 2160/43 order under section 27(1), Universities Act No. 16 of 1978) by the Ministry of Higher Education, Technology and Innovation of Sri Lanka.

1.1 Introduction - Part 2
The Vavuniya Campus of the University of Jaffna was then elevated to a separate state university and established as the 'University of Vavuniya, Sri Lanka' by an extraordinary gazette issued on June 8, 2021. Accordingly, the University of Vavuniya became the 17th state University in Sri Lanka with effective from 1st August 2021.

1.1 Introduction - Part 3
The permanent site of the University of Vavuniya is about ten kilometres away from Vavuniya in the Vavuniya-Mannar road at Sopalapuliyankulam, Pampaimadu. One hundred and sixty acres of land was allocated and reserved for the construction of academic, administrative, and residential buildings.

1.1 Introduction - Part 4
Vavuniya, in the southern part of the Northern Province, is a melting pot of cultures from the Vanni region and the north-central region of Sri Lanka. A culture that has been influenced and shaped by the Vanniyas (of whom the King Pandaravanniyan is a prominent example). This district has ties even with the Paduvankarai regions that extend to the Southernmost part of the Northern and Eastern provinces - an indication of how the Vanniya people have contributed to the rich culture of the Tamil speaking societies of Sri Lanka.

1.1 Introduction - Part 5
Vavuniya is renowned for its mild climate, which provides a pleasant change from the usual arid conditions of the coastal regions of the Northern and Eastern provinces. As such, it provides an ideal setting for the Faculty of Applied Science, with a pleasant environment to indulge in educational and extra-curricular activities.

1.1 Introduction - Part 6
Further, as per present conditions, Vavuniya provides a strategic location that acts as a transit point for the movement of people as well as various financial and industrial activities/processes. Thus, Vavuniya is expected to grow into a prominent financial and cultural hub in Sri Lanka.

1.1 Introduction - Part 7
The Faculty of Applied Science as an academic organization has a flexible, friendly, and conducive internal environment that allows for effective teaching, learning, and research. This is due to the fact that the faculty has a unique signatured culture where the student and staff interactions are high-level and one-to-one attention is administered to the students by the teachers.

1.1 Introduction - Part 8
Further, the faculty has very strong ties with the community of Vavuniya and it is seen as a key and prominent player in the advisory capacities of all development endeavours taking place in the locality. The Faculty of Applied Science of the University of Vavuniya consists of two departments, namely the Department of Physical Science and the Department of Bio-science.

1.1 Introduction - Part 1
The Department of Bio-science is one of the departments in the Faculty of Applied Science of the University of Vavuniya, commenced in 1997.

1.1 Introduction - Part 2
The Department of Bio-science offers the course units for the bachelors degree programme in Environmental Science. The Syllabi has been drafted with different courses in Environmental Science with an emphasis on fields of technological importance.

1.1 Introduction - Part 3
The major objective of the department is to train the undergraduates to suit the latest trends in the industry, research, and development of the national economy through course work, practical sessions, industrial training, and research projects pertaining to Environmental Science.

1.1 Introduction - Part 4
The revised curriculum has been approved by the Council and the UGC. The curriculum was revised in such a way to offer the Bachelor of Science Honours in Environmental Science as a four-year honours degree program.

1.1 Introduction - Part 5
The program is designed in line with the Outcome Based Education and Learner Centered Teaching (OBE-LCT) and Sri Lanka Qualifications Framework (SLQF).

1.1 Introduction - Part 1
The Department of Physical Science of University of Vavuniya came into existence with the commencement of the Faculty of Applied Science in 1997. Initially, the department offered the course units for a degree programme named Applied Mathematics and Computing.

1.1 Introduction - Part 2
Then the Information and Communication Technology Degree programme was introduced in 2006 for all streams of advanced level students. The Applied Mathematics and Computing Degree programme was also revised and the three-year degree programme named Applied Mathematics and Computing and the four-year degree programme named Computer Science.

1.1 Introduction - Part 3
The major commitment of the department is to provide up-to-date knowledge in Mathematics and Statistics, Computer Science, and Information Technology to undergraduates through coursework, practical sessions, industrial training, and research projects.

1.1 Introduction - Part 4
The Information and Communication Technology programme was revised as Information Technology degree programme in 2018. The department has been offering the course units for the Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics and Computing, Bachelor of Science Honours in Computer Science, Bachelor of Science in Information Technology, and Bachelor of Science Honours in Information Technology from the academic year 2017/18 onwards based on the curriculum revision in 2018.

1.1 Introduction - Part 5
The revised curricula are in line with the Outcome Based Education and Learner Centered Teaching (OBE-LCT), Sri Lanka Qualification Framework (SLQF), IEEE/ACM, and Subject Benchmark Statements of IT (SBS-IT) guidelines.

1.2 Officers of the University of Vavuniya
The University of Vavuniya's leadership comprises distinguished academics and administrators. Dr. S. Mohanadas serves as Chancellor, with Prof. T. Mangaleswaran holding the position of Vice Chancellor. The faculty deans include Dr. (Mrs.) J. Nimalan (Applied Science), Prof. Y. Nanthagoban (Business Studies), and Mr. V. Senthooran (Technological Studies). Administrative leadership consists of Mr. N. Rajavisahan as Registrar and Mr. L. Ramramanan as Bursar, overseeing university operations and financial management respectively.

1.7 Faculty Quality Assurance Cell (FQAC) - Part 1
Faculty Quality Assurance Cell is functioning at the faculty level to ensure that the quality and standards of the academic programmes offered by the Faculty to meet the changing demands and challenges of higher education sector.

1.7 Faculty Quality Assurance Cell (FQAC) - Part 2
The objective of this FQAC is to provide suggestions or recommendations and facilitation to implement and monitor the best management practices to ensure quality principles at the faculty level for an effective learning environment according to the SLQF guidelines and relevant benchmarks, student and staff support services, and other various aspects.

1.7 Faculty Quality Assurance Cell (FQAC) - Part 3
FQAC conducts regular meetings with the members to discuss quality aspects, faculty awards and Dean's list, conducts students' feedback and satisfaction surveys, analyzes the results, and communicates with the appropriate staff members for verification and acceptance.

1.7 Faculty Quality Assurance Cell (FQAC) - Part 4
Furthermore, FQAC takes a significant role in facilitating institutional and program reviews and undertakes follow-up actions on the recommendations given during the above reviews and finally reports to the Faculty Board for decision making.

1.7 Faculty Quality Assurance Cell (FQAC) - Part 5
The meeting minutes and documentation are regularly updated on the FQAC official website linked to CQA and ensuring transparency, accountability, affordability, and accessibility to both staff and students, and adding value to the Faculty of Applied Science. Best practices show the path to success through continuous improvement, leading to the benchmark of excellence.

2.1.1 The Title of the Degree Programme
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The Department of Bio-science offers a four year degree programme titled as Bachelor of Science Honours in Environmental Science. The abbreviation of Bachelor of Science Honours in Environmental Science degree is BScHons (Env Sc).

metadata.title: 2.1 The Structure of the Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.1.1 The Title of the Degree Programme

content:
2.1.2 Admission Requirements - Part 1
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The Bachelor of Science Honours in Environmental Science programme admits students annually under the governance of the University Grants Commission. Applicants must meet specific academic requirements at the GCE Advanced Level, including minimum 'S' grades in both Biology and Chemistry as mandatory subjects. These foundational science prerequisites ensure students possess the necessary background for rigorous environmental studies.

2.1.2 Admission Requirements - Part 2
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
In addition to the compulsory science subjects, candidates must demonstrate proficiency in one optional subject from: Agricultural Science, Higher Mathematics, Mathematics, Combined Mathematics, or Physics, achieving at least an 'S' grade. This requirement allows students to enter the programme through different academic pathways while maintaining strong quantitative or additional scientific competencies.

2.1.2 Admission Requirements - Part 3
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The admission process evaluates both scientific aptitude and broader academic capabilities through this combination of mandatory and optional subject requirements. The annual intake ensures a consistent cohort of students meeting these established standards, prepared for the challenges of the degree programme's interdisciplinary environmental science curriculum.

2.1.4 Program Overview - Part 1
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
This study program is designed to offer theoretical knowledge, practical skills, problem solving, and creative thinking. The course units are distributed at four levels – Level 1, 2, 3, and 4. The proposed study program is credit based and an academic year is divided into two semesters, each with 15 weeks duration. One credit shall constitute 50 notional learning hours.

2.1.4 Program Overview - Part 2
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
Contents in a theory course may consist of one credit (50 notional learning hours), 2 credits (100 notional learning hours), and 3 credits (150 notional learning hours) while a practical course may vary from one credit (30 to 45 hours) depending on the practical knowledge required in the respective disciplines. In many course units, the practical is designed as a component along with the theory part.

2.1.4 Program Overview - Part 3
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
Students entering the BScHons (Env Sc) are required to follow core course units in all four levels and auxiliary course units in Levels 1, 2, and 3. The most important course units are referred to as core course units while the elective course units are chosen by students in their field of interest. The number of credits from core course units is 104 and from elective course units is 16, totaling 120 credits.

2.1.4 Program Overview - Part 4
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
Level 1 Semester I incorporates fundamentals of Environmental Science in Chemistry, Botany, and Zoology plus Basic Mathematics and IT. From Level 1 Semester II to Level 4, the curriculum covers detailed environmental science topics. Level 4 focuses on a research project and industrial training, with topics of regional/national interest related to natural resources and environmental issues.

2.1.4 Program Overview - Part 5
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
Field reports and the 'Seminar' course unit facilitate Student Centered Learning (SCL), developing skills in communication, teamwork, leadership, problem solving, data analysis, and IT applications for environmental management.

2.1.4 Program Overview - Part 6
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
Auxiliary course units (14 credits total) are offered in Levels 1-3, including English Language, Social Harmony, Communication Skills, and Career Guidance. These develop graduate personality traits and are required for degree completion, though not included in GPA calculations.

2.1.5 Credit System Overview
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The programme employs a credit-based system where all course units carry specific credit values, with one credit equivalent to 50 notional learning hours. Courses follow a four-digit coding system: the first digit indicates the academic level, the second denotes the semester, the third represents the course sequence, and the fourth digit shows the credit value. This standardized coding, detailed in Figure 2.1, provides a clear framework for academic progression.

2.1.5 Core Course Structure
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
Core courses are designed to develop essential professional skills including communication, leadership, problem-solving, IT proficiency, and managerial capabilities. The curriculum blends theoretical and practical components, with only one exclusively practical unit. Students complete 15 credits per semester in Levels 1-3, with Level 4 offering 19 credits (selecting 12 from 17 options) in Semester I and 11 credits (choosing 4 from 6 electives) in Semester II, totaling 120 core credits.

2.1.5 Auxiliary Courses
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The programme includes mandatory auxiliary courses (14 credits total) spanning English Language I & II, Social Harmony, Communication Skills, Career Guidance, and Management Training. While these interdisciplinary courses don't factor into GPA calculations, they must be completed satisfactorily for degree conferral. As shown in Table 2.1, these courses are strategically distributed across Levels 1-3 to complement core disciplinary training.

2.1.6 Volume of Learning - Part 1
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The four-year Honours programme requires completion of 134 total credits, comprising 120 core course credits and 14 auxiliary credits. Students must achieve minimum grades of C in English Language I & II, and D+ in other auxiliary courses. These requirements ensure comprehensive subject mastery while maintaining essential language proficiency standards throughout the degree.

2.1.6 Volume of Learning - Part 2
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
The final year features significant research and professional experience components. Students undertake a semester-long research project under the supervision of senior academics from universities or research institutes. Additionally, they complete a two-month full-time industrial training placement worth 1 credit, providing practical exposure to environmental science applications in professional settings.

2.1.6 Volume of Learning - Part 3
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
This balanced structure of coursework, research, and industrial training ensures graduates develop both theoretical knowledge and practical competencies. The 134-credit requirement combines rigorous academic study with hands-on learning experiences, preparing students for diverse career paths in environmental science while meeting national qualification framework standards.

2.1.7 Opting for General Degree
2.1 The Structure of the Programme
During the fourth year of study, a student following an honours degree programme may opt for a general degree before the submission of the thesis of the research project with valid reason. The final acceptance to opt for the general degree will be subjected to the recommendation of the Faculty Board of Applied Sciences and the Senate. If a student wishes to complete his/her studies in three years, he/she has to complete a minimum of 90 credits of core course units and 14 credits of auxiliary course units during three years of study to obtain the degree titled Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science.

2.2.1 Programme Objectives - Part 1
2.2 Degree Programme Objectives and Graduate Profile
The Bachelor of Science Honours in Environmental Science program aims to produce graduates capable of solving environmental problems using scientific approaches. The main objective focuses on developing professionals who can address both local and global environmental challenges while meeting industry and research needs for sustainable development.

2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The degree programme uses two main evaluation methods: In-course Assessments (ICA) and End-semester Examinations (ESE). ICA are formative assessments conducted during regular course sessions, including field assignments, quizzes, viva-voce, and other assessments. Attendance is mandatory for all ICA components, and these marks contribute to the final grade. ESE are summative examinations administered by the university's examination branch at the end of each semester.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Part 1

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
For theory courses, the final mark (M1) is calculated using the formula: 70% of the end-semester theory exam mark (T) plus 30% of the average in-course assessment marks (A1). Practical courses use a different weighting: 60% of the end-semester practical exam mark (P) plus 40% of the average practical assessment marks (A2).

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Part 2

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Courses combining theory and practical components use a credit-weighted formula. The final mark (M) is calculated by combining the theory component (M1) and practical component (M2) according to their respective credit values (Ct and Cp). Importantly, scoring below 40% in either the theory or practical component automatically results in an 'E' grade, regardless of the overall average mark.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Part 3

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The industrial training evaluation is conducted by a specially appointed panel. This panel is selected by the Head of Department with approval from the Faculty Board, and consists of three members: one senior staff member from the training institution where the student completed their placement, plus two senior faculty members from the Bio-science Department.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 1

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Students are assessed across ten key criteria during their industrial training. Professional conduct factors include attendance and punctuality (10% of total marks), reliability when working independently (5%), work ethic and industriousness (5%), enthusiasm for the work (5%), personal demeanor (5%), and demonstration of leadership qualities (10%). These criteria evaluate the student's professional development during the placement.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 2

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The quality of work produced during training accounts for 10% of the evaluation. The largest portion of the assessment (50% combined) focuses on the training report: its preparation (30%), oral presentation (10%), and viva-voce examination (10%). These components test the student's ability to document, analyze, and communicate their industrial training experience.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 3

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 4
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
All evaluation components sum to 100%, providing a comprehensive assessment of both the practical experience and academic reflection aspects of the industrial training. The balanced scoring system ensures students are evaluated on both their professional performance during the placement and their ability to synthesize the learning experience.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Industrial Training Part 4

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Project Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The research project evaluation assesses students across five key components: the initial project proposal (10%), project execution and conduct (20%), final written report/thesis (40%), oral presentation (15%), and viva-voce examination (15%). This comprehensive system evaluates both the research process and final outcomes.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Project Part 1

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Project Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Evaluation is conducted by a three-member panel appointed through an official process. The Head of Department nominates members, with recommendations from the Faculty Board and final approval by the Senate. The panel consists of the project supervisor plus two examiners - one internal faculty member (excluding the supervisor) and one external academic from another institution.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Project Part 2

content:
2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Project Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The supervisor evaluates the project proposal and research conduct, contributing 30% of the total grade. The two examiners collectively assess the written report, oral presentation, and viva-voce, accounting for the remaining 70%. This balanced approach ensures both the research process and final deliverables are properly evaluated.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.1 Evaluation Methods - Project Part 3

content:
2.3.2 Grading System - Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The programme uses a detailed letter grade system with corresponding grade points. The grading scale ranges from A+ (80-100%, 4.0 grade points) down to E (0-29%, 0.0 grade points). A minimum grade of C- (40-44%, 1.7 grade points) is required to pass any course. The E grade represents failing performance and requires course repetition.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.2 Grading System - Part 1

content:
2.3.2 Grading System - Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Grade Point Average (GPA) is calculated by dividing the sum of all (course credits × grade points earned) by the total number of credits attempted. This credit-weighted system ensures larger courses have proportionally greater impact on the cumulative GPA. Final GPAs are rounded to two decimal places for official records.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.2 Grading System - Part 2

content:
2.3.2 Grading System - Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Key academic regulations include: the 40% minimum passing threshold (C- grade), automatic failure for any course receiving an E grade (below 30%), and the standard two-decimal place precision for final GPA calculations. These policies ensure consistent academic standards across all courses in the programme.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.2 Grading System - Part 3

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The programme utilizes two main assessment types: In-course Assessments (ICA) and End-semester Examinations (ESE). ICA are conducted throughout the academic session by individual course lecturers, with results promptly communicated to students. These assessments occur during regular lecture periods and form a continuous evaluation component.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 1

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
End-semester Examinations are centrally administered according to the faculty's academic calendar. The University Examination Branch coordinates these comprehensive tests, with schedules determined jointly by the Dean and Department Heads. A rigorous three-step approval process ensures result validity: initial review by the Faculty Pre-Exam Board, formal Senate approval, and final publication through the Dean's office.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 2

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Final result processing involves multiple quality checks. The Examination Branch compiles all assessment data before the Vice-Chancellor's Exam Board convenes. This authoritative body officially releases three key academic metrics: semester-specific GPAs, cumulative level GPAs, and final degree classifications including Overall GPA and Honours designations, ensuring transparent and standardized academic recognition.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 3

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Resit Policy Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Students must resit examinations if they receive grades below minimum thresholds: below C- (40%) for core/elective courses, below C (45%) for English Language I/II, or below D+ (35%) for other auxiliary courses. These requirements ensure all students meet foundational competency standards before progressing in the programme.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Resit Policy Part 1

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Resit Policy Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The resit process has specific regulations: Students who miss exams must attempt them at the next available opportunity, which counts as their resit attempt. Medical absences require documentation - students must submit a medical certificate within 14 days of the missed exam, with approval from both the Committee for Medical Certificate & Mercy Chance (CMCMC) and Senate for eligibility at the next examination session.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Resit Policy Part 2

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Resit Policy Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Resit grading maintains original In-course Assessment (ICA) marks, combining them with new End-semester Examination (ESE) scores. Strict policies prohibit ICA resits entirely - students missing ICA components must notify lecturers immediately and complete requirements before the ESE. No makeup opportunities exist after the ESE period, emphasizing the importance of timely participation in all assessments.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Resit Policy Part 3

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The programme employs a dual assessment system consisting of In-course Assessments (ICA) and End-semester Examinations (ESE). ICA are conducted throughout the academic term by individual lecturers, with all assessments completed during regular class sessions. Lecturers are responsible for scheduling these evaluations and promptly communicating results to students, ensuring continuous feedback on academic progress.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 1

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
End-semester Examinations are centralized assessments administered according to the faculty's published academic calendar. The University Examination Branch oversees all ESE logistics, with specific examination timetables established through collaboration between the Dean's office and Department Heads. A rigorous three-tier approval process ensures result validity: initial verification by the Faculty Pre-Exam Board, formal ratification by the University Senate, and final publication through the Dean's office.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 2

content:
2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Examination Branch consolidates all assessment results before the Vice-Chancellor convenes the final Exam Board. This governing body authorizes the release of comprehensive academic records including: semester-specific Grade Point Averages (GPA), cumulative level GPAs tracking progress through the programme, and final degree classifications that incorporate both Overall GPA calculations and Honours designations based on academic performance benchmarks.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.3 Examination Process - Part 3

content:
2.3.4 Award of Degree - Honours Requirements Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
To qualify for the Bachelor of Science Honours in Environmental Science (SLQF Level 6), students must complete 120 credits of core courses across all four academic levels. Additionally, they must achieve minimum grades in auxiliary courses: at least a C grade in English Language I and II, and D+ or above in other auxiliary courses. These requirements ensure comprehensive subject mastery and language proficiency.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.4 Award of Degree - Honours Requirements Part 1

content:
2.3.4 Award of Degree - Honours Requirements Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Students must maintain a minimum Overall GPA (OGPA) of 2.00 across all academic work and complete all degree requirements within a maximum of six years. The OGPA calculation incorporates performance in all courses, with particular emphasis on core environmental science subjects. The six-year timeframe allows for flexible study while maintaining academic standards.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.4 Award of Degree - Honours Requirements Part 2

content:
2.3.4 Award of Degree - Honours Requirements Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Key programme notes highlight that successful completion of all core courses is mandatory, with stricter English language requirements compared to other auxiliary courses. The time-limited completion policy ensures degree relevance, while the comprehensive OGPA calculation reflects overall academic achievement in both theoretical and practical components of the programme.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.4 Award of Degree - Honours Requirements Part 3

content:
2.3.4 Award of Degree - General Degree Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science (SLQF Level 5) requires completion of 90 core course credits across the first three academic levels. Students must achieve minimum grades in auxiliary courses, including at least a C grade in both English Language I and II, and D+ or above in other auxiliary courses. These requirements maintain fundamental competency standards while offering a shorter study path than the honours programme.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.4 Award of Degree - General Degree Part 1

content:
2.3.4 Award of Degree - General Degree Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
To qualify, students must attain a minimum Overall GPA of 2.00 based on their performance in Levels 1 through 3, and complete all requirements within five academic years. The GPA calculation excludes Level 4 work, focusing instead on foundational and intermediate coursework. This accelerated timeframe accommodates students seeking earlier degree completion while ensuring academic rigor.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.4 Award of Degree - General Degree Part 2

content:
2.3.4 Award of Degree - General Degree Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Key distinctions from the honours programme include the reduced 90-credit requirement (versus 120 for honours) and condensed five-year completion window. While maintaining the same English language proficiency standards, the general degree evaluates performance only through Level 3, making it an appropriate option for students pursuing different career timelines or pathways.

content:
2.3.5 Award of Classes - Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Honours degree classification system recognizes academic excellence through three tiers of achievement. First Class honours requires an exceptional Overall GPA (OGPA) of 3.70 or above, while Second Class is divided into Upper Division (OGPA 3.30-3.69) and Lower Division (OGPA 3.00-3.29). All classifications demand completion of the programme within four academic years and fulfillment of the standard honours degree eligibility criteria.

metadata.title: 2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
metadata.subtitle: 2.3.5 Award of Classes - Part 1

content:
2.3.5 Award of Classes - Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Board of Examiners holds sole authority for determining class awards, basing decisions strictly on the final OGPA and adherence to the four-year completion timeframe. This rigorous classification system ensures consistent standards across cohorts, with the OGPA serving as the primary differentiator between degree classes. All candidates must first meet the base requirements for honours degree eligibility before being considered for classification.

metadata.subtitle: 2.3.5 Award of Classes - Part 2

content:
2.3.5 Award of Classes - Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Key aspects of the classification process include the universal four-year completion requirement for all honours classes and the exclusive use of OGPA thresholds for differentiation. The system maintains consistent baseline requirements while rewarding varying levels of academic achievement, with First Class honours representing the programme's highest distinction for outstanding scholarly performance.

content:
2.3.5 Award of Classes - General Degree Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The General Degree classification follows a three-tier system similar to the Honours programme, but with modified requirements. First Class requires an Overall GPA (OGPA) of 3.70 or above, Second Class Upper Division needs 3.30-3.69, and Second Class Lower Division requires 3.00-3.29. All classifications must be completed within three academic years, reflecting the programme's condensed timeframe compared to the four-year Honours degree.

content:
2.3.5 Award of Classes - General Degree Part 2
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Board of Examiners awards classifications based strictly on final OGPA and timely completion within three years. While maintaining rigorous standards, the General Degree (SLQF Level 5) differs substantially from the Honours programme through its reduced 90-credit requirement and accelerated completion timeline. These adjustments accommodate students pursuing different academic or career pathways while still recognizing exceptional achievement.

2.3.5 Award of Classes - General Degree Part 3
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
Key distinctions from the Honours degree include the three-year completion window (versus four years), the 90-credit baseline (versus 120 credits), and the SLQF Level 5 designation. Despite these differences, the classification system maintains parallel GPA thresholds, ensuring consistent standards of academic excellence across both degree types while respecting their different structures and purposes.

2.3.6 Award of Diploma/Higher Diploma - Part 1
2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The programme offers two early exit qualifications: the Higher Diploma (SLQF Level 4) and Diploma (SLQF Level 3). The Higher Diploma requires completion of 60 core credits across Levels 1 and 2, with minimum grades of C in ACU1113 and ACU2113, and D+ in other non-English auxiliary courses. Students must maintain a GPA of 2.00 in both academic levels to qualify for this intermediate credential.

2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
The Diploma option provides recognition for students completing Level 1 (30 core credits) with a C grade in ACU1113 and D+ in other auxiliary courses, while maintaining a 2.00 GPA. Both qualifications maintain the programme's English language standards, offering students academic recognition if they choose to exit before completing the full degree.

2.3 Evaluation System of the Degree Programme
These exit pathways feature progressive credit requirements - 30 credits for the Diploma and an additional 30 for the Higher Diploma - while maintaining consistent GPA thresholds and language proficiency standards. The tiered structure allows for flexible academic progression while ensuring all credentials meet established quality benchmarks in environmental science education.

content:
Level 1 Course Overview - Part 1
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The Level 1 curriculum begins with foundational courses in Semester I, including Environmental Chemistry (ENS1112, 2 credits) with 30 theory hours, and Chemical Analysis (ENS1121, 1 credit) as a fully practical course with 30 lab hours. Cell Biology (ENS1132) combines 25 theory hours with 10 practical hours across its 2 credits, while Plant Biology (ENS1142) offers a more practice-oriented approach with 20 theory hours and 30 practical hours for 2 credits.

Level 1 Course Overview - Part 2
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Semester I continues with Animal Biology (ENS1153, 3 credits) featuring balanced 30 theory and 45 practical hours, and Basic Mathematics (ENS1162, 2 credits) as a purely theoretical course. Students also take Fundamentals of IT (CCCU1113, 3 credits) with equal theory and practical components, and English Language I (ACU1113, 3 credits) focusing on 45 theory hours for language development.

Level 1 Course Overview - Part 3
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Semester II introduces applied courses like Environment and Agriculture (ENS1212, 2 credits) and Soil Science (ENS1223, 3 credits) with significant practical components (45 hours). Environmental Sanitation (ENS1232) blends 25 theory hours with 15 practical hours across 2 credits, while Principles of Economics (ENS1242) provides 30 theory hours of foundational knowledge.

Level 1 Course Overview - Part 4
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The semester concludes with Earth Sciences (ENS1253, 3 credits) as a theoretical course, Environmental Microbiology (ENS1263, 3 credits) combining 40 theory hours with 15 practical hours, and Social Harmony (ACU1212, 2 credits) completing the auxiliary course requirements. This balanced curriculum establishes both scientific fundamentals and essential complementary skills.

Level 2 Course Overview - Part 1
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The Level 2 curriculum builds on foundational knowledge with more specialized courses. Semester I includes Biodiversity & Conservation (ENS2112) with 25 theory and 15 practical hours, and Food, Nutrition & Environment (ENS2123) offering comprehensive coverage through 40 theory and 15 practical hours. Analytical Chemistry (ENS2132) provides essential lab skills with 25 theory and 10 practical hours, while Animal Behavior (ENS2142) combines 25 theory hours with 15 hours of practical observation.

Level 2 Course Overview - Part 2
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The first semester continues with theoretical courses like Forest Environmental Biology & Management (ENS2152, 30 theory hours) and Resource & Environmental Economics (ENS2162). Sustainable Development (ENS2172) rounds out the core courses with 30 theory hours, while English II (ACU2113) develops advanced communication skills through 45 theory hours.

Level 2 Course Overview - Part 3
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Semester II focuses on applied environmental sciences, beginning with Applied Hydrology (ENS2213) featuring 40 theory and 15 practical hours, and theoretical Applied Ecology (ENS2222). Environmental Disaster Management (ENS2233) provides 45 comprehensive theory hours, while Energy & Environment (ENS2242) balances 25 theory hours with 15 practical applications.

Level 2 Course Overview - Part 4
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The semester concludes with Ecotourism (ENS2252) emphasizing practical skills through 20 theory and 30 practical hours, and Environmental Pollution & Control (ENS2263) with 40 theory and 15 practical hours. Communication & Soft Skills (ACU2212) completes the auxiliary requirements with 30 theory hours, preparing students for professional environmental work.

Level 3 Course Overview - Part 1
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Level 3 introduces advanced technical courses beginning with GIS & Remote Sensing (ENS3113), offering balanced 30 theory and 30 practical hours. Wildlife Conservation (ENS3122) combines 25 theory hours with field applications, while Environmental Policies & Law (ENS3132) provides 30 theory hours of regulatory knowledge. Solid Waste Management (ENS3143) and Environmental Biotechnology (ENS3153) both emphasize practical problem-solving with 40 theory hours complemented by 15 practical hours each.

Level 3 Course Overview - Part 2
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The first semester continues with Industrial Chemistry (ENS3162) featuring 25 theory and 15 lab hours, and concludes with Career Guidance (ACU3112), a 30-hour theory course preparing students for professional pathways. This semester's blend of technical and career-focused courses bridges academic learning with real-world applications.

Level 3 Course Overview - Part 3
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Semester II begins with Statistics for Environmental Science (ENS3213), equally dividing 30 theory and practical hours. Environmental Impact Assessment (ENS3222) provides 30 theory hours of regulatory training, while Marine Environment Management (ENS3232) and Wastewater Treatment (ENS3242) each combine 25 theory hours with 15 practical applications. The 1-credit Seminar course (ENS3251) involves 50 notional hours of independent research and presentation.

Level 3 Course Overview - Part 4
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The curriculum concludes with Biomolecules (ENS3262) offering 25 theory and 15 practical hours, Environmental Toxicology (ENS3273) with 40 theory and 15 lab hours, and Management & Entrepreneurial Skills (ACU3212). This final semester emphasizes professional competencies through its combination of scientific rigor and business acumen development.

Level 4 Course Overview - Part 1
2.4 Curriculum Layout
The final year begins with three core courses in Semester I: Project Planning & Management (ENS4112, 30 theory hours), Cleaner Production (ENS4122) blending 20 theory with 30 practical hours, and Research Methods (ENS4133) with 40 theory and 10 practical hours. Students then select 12 credits from specialized electives including Limnology (ENS4142), Advanced Water Treatment (ENS4152), and Groundwater Management (ENS4163), allowing customization based on research interests and career goals.

Level 4 Course Overview - Part 2
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Additional elective options include Environmental Microbiology (ENS4173) with extensive lab work, Advanced Spectroscopy (ENS4183) for analytical skills, Climate Change (ENS4192) as a theoretical course, Environmental Communication (ENS41(10)2) for outreach training, and Metrology (ENS41(11)3) covering measurement standards. These electives provide advanced, focused study in key environmental science specializations.

Level 4 Course Overview - Part 3
2.4 Curriculum Layout
Semester II focuses on professional development through Industrial Training (ENS4211, 200 notional hours) and a substantial Research Project (ENS4226, 600 notional hours). Students complete their specialization by choosing 4 credits from electives like Environmental System Modeling (ENS4232), Plantation Forestry (ENS4242), or Weed Management (ENS4252), applying their accumulated knowledge to real-world challenges.
